Award.AwardTitle: DynSyst_Special_Topics: Dynamics Of Turbulent Flow Via Unstable Exact Navier-Stokes Solutions: Connecting Theory & Numerics With Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research program is to develop and to test experimentally a revolutionary new approach to modeling and predicting two-dimensional turbulent flows. A set of weakly unstable invariant Navier-Stokes solutions will be identified and transitions between invariant solutions will be characterized to provide a coarse global description of the nonlinear dynamics of turbulent flow. Quasi-2D flow in a shallow electrolyte layer continually driven by Lorentz forces provides the setting for theoretical, analytic and experimental development of this approach. Novel and proven techniques, such as periodic orbit theory, group representation theory, Krylov-subspace numerical methods, Newton and variational solvers will be used to develop this viewpoint, which will be tested in experiments where the flow can be measured with full spatial and temporal resolution throughout the entire flow domain.

If successful, the results of this research will impact several areas of science, engineering, and medicine. Although the focus of this investigation is on fluid turbulence in two dimensions, the proposed approach has the potential to provide new ways to model, and ultimately control, a wide range of spatiotemporally chaotic systems, such as magnetic confinement fusion reactors and abnormal cardiac dynamics (from mild arrhythmias to potentially lethal fibrillation). The most immediate practical application, however, is the reduction of turbulent drag responsible for a significant part of the fuel consumed in the automotive, aviation, and shipping industries. Even an incremental reduction of drag by the proposed flow control methodology would have a tremendous economic impact. All software and data produced by the research program will be made publicly available with a central aim of lowering the barrier of entry to dynamical systems research by providing well-documented, easy-to-use interfaces to state-of-the-art numerical algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid turbulence is omnipresent. Indeed, the flows of air and water 
 
surrounding us are typically turbulent. Turbulent flows are characterized by 
 
complicated, irregular, almost random patterns. Oddly enough, the governing law 
 
of fluid dynamics - the Navier-Stokes equation - is completely deterministic: the 
 
evolution of the flow is entirely determined by initial conditions, i.e., the 
 
velocity field of the fluid at some instant in the past. Understanding how 
 
apparently random dynamics can arise in such a deterministic system and how we 
 
describe - and forecast - these dynamics remains one of the greatest unsolved 
 
problems of classical physics.
 
 The key insight and the biggest hurdle to understanding turbulence is the
 
nonlinearity of the Navier-Stokes equation, which implies that solutions 
 
describing turbulent flow cannot be found in analytic form. On the other hand, 
 
fully-resolved direct numerical simulations of the Navier-Stokes equation are 
 
computationally so expensive that real-time forecasting of turbulence remains out 
 
of reach despite the advances in computational hardware and numerical methods. 
 
Due to these limitations, fluid turbulence has been described primarily using a 
 
statistical framework which, despite being successful in characterizing some 
 
aspects of turbulence, falls short in providing a tractable means to predict the 
 
evolution of a turbulent flow even over relatively short time scales.
 
 Recent studies have approached turbulence from a new perspective, which stems 
 
from the observation that turbulent flows often exhibit recognizable transient 
 
patterns that recur over time. These patterns, called "exact coherent structures" 
 
(ECS), are related to a class of unstable solutions of the Navier-Stokes 
 
equation, which can only be found numerically. The ECS exist in the same 
 
parameter regime where turbulence is found, but being unstable, they are observed 
 
only fleetingly. It has therefore been speculated that it may be possible to 
 
construct a predictive description of fluid turbulence as a deterministic walk
 
between neighborhoods of a hierarchy of ECS.
 
 The objective of our research was to test, in numerical simulations and 
 
experiment, whether ECS do indeed play a dynamically important role, with each 
 
ECS guiding the evolution of turbulent flow over a finite period of time. 
 
Furthermore, we wanted to test whether the transition from one neighborhood to 
 
another is random or follows a prescribed route, which again corresponds to a 
 
solution of the Navier-Stokes equation connecting different ECS. ECS and 
 
connections between them can be thought of as a map of cities and roads between 
 
them, with turbulent flow as a car driving down a road. While the "roadmap" is 
 
static, it is the motion along the "roadways" that represents the evolution of 
 
turbulent flow, with apparent randomness arising from the sensitive dependence of 
 
any route on the initial conditions.
 
 To facilitate these tests we focused on a nearly-two-dimensional flow in a 
 
thin fluid layer. In the experiment the flow is driven by an electromagnetic 
 
Lorentz force, which can be controlled much more precisely by varying the 
 
electric current flowing through the fluid electrolyte. We have also derived a 
 
two-dimensional mathematical model of the flow by depth-averaging the Navier-
 
Stokes equation and validated the model by comparing its predictions with 
 
experimental observations. This model has been used to describe the transition 
 
from the (simple and predictable) laminar flow to turbulence. Furthermore, we 
 
have identified several tens of ECS using initial conditions obtained by 
 
analyzing both numerical and experimental data and have demonstrated that these 
 
ECS do indeed play a dynamically important role in both experiments and 
 
simulations. 
 
 In the process we have made two unexpected discoveries. We found that the 
 
transition to turbulence is mediated by a temporally quasi-periodic solution, 
 
while the vast majority of ECS correspond to equilibrium (time-independent) 
 
solutions of the model. This discovery directly contradicts, and calls for a 
 
through reassessment of the previously hypothesized scenario accepted by most 
 
researchers in the field, that turbulence should be described using hierarchies 
 
of temporally periodic solutions. Furthermore, we have developed a novel 
 
numerical method that, for the first time, allows computation of not only the 
 
unstable solutions describing ECS, but also the connections between them, which 
 
is crucial for our ability to construct "roadmaps" of turbulent flows.  In sum, 
 
we have shown that it is possible to make forecasts over time intervals of 
 
moderate length by using the "roadmap" based on ECS and their connections. We 
 
have demonstrated that connections originating near an ECS "guide" all turbulent 
 
solutions in their vicinity, in both experiments and numerical simulations, over 
 
many characteristic time scales, when the flow loses any resemblance to the 
 
initial condition.
